subject: RE: [junit] Re: How to test console output?
msgSnippet: ... They re not in the constructor. It s just a strange naming convention that makes it look like a constructor. J. B. Rainsberger, President, Diaspar Software
messageBody:
>So said Ilja Preuss on 2003-07-31 --------------------
>J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>>> So said jxingtang on 2003-07-30 --------------------
>
>>> public class MyClassTest extends TestCase
>>> {
>>> private MyClass MyTestObj = null;
>>>
>>> private StringWriter StrWriter = null;
>>>
>>> // Clip ...
>>>
>>> protected void setUp()
>>> {
>>> StrWriter = new StringWriter();
>>> PrintWriter prWriter = new PrintWriter( StrWriter );
>>> TestObj = new MyClass( prWriter );
>>> }
>>>
>>> public DumpOutputTest()
>>> {
>>> Vector testParams = new Vector();
>>> // Testcase 1
>>> testParams.addElement( "A" );
>>> testParams.addElement( "B" );
>>> testParams.addElement( "C" );
>>>
>>> TestObj.DumpOutput( testParams );
>>>
>>> String outStr = StrWriter.toString();
>>>
>>> // Code to evaluate outStr
>>> // Clip ....
>>>
>>> // Clean buffer of StringWriter
>>> StringBuffer sbuff = StrWriter.getBuffer();
>>> sbuff.delete( 0, outStr.length());
>>>
>>> // Testcase 2
>>> testParams.addElement( "X" );
>>> testParams.addElement( "Y" );
>>> testParams.addElement( "Z" );
>>>
>>> TestObj.DumpOutput( testParams );
>>>
>>> String outStr = StrWriter.toString();
>>>
>>> // Code to evaluate outStr
>>> // Clip ....
>>> }
>>>
>>> // Clip ...
>>> };
>>>
>>> Please give your valuable comments for my further correction and
>>> improvements.
>>
>> Why are you writing multiple tests in a single method? Each
>> test should be its own method. You defeat the point of JUnit by using
>> it this way.
>
>Additionally, your tests shouldn't be in the constructor, but in test
>methods.

They're not in the constructor. It's just a strange naming convention that makes it look like a constructor.


J. B. Rainsberger,
